title: Are Vikings Irish or Scottish? - Quora

response.answer_text: The Vikings were Scandinavians who from the 8th to 11th centuries, raided and traded from their Northern European bases across wide areas of Europe, and explored westwards to Iceland, Greenland and Vinland The term in modern English extends the meaning to include the inhabitants of Norse home communities during what has become known as the Viking Age 798–1066AD. This period of Nordic military, mercantile and demographic expansion constitutes an important element in the early medieval history of Scandinavia, Estonia, parts of Russia, Ireland, Britain, France and even Sicily. Many towns were established and grown in both Scotland and Ireland by the Vikings. Limerick, Dublin and Waterford for example. So Vikings are both Irish and Scottish and make up between 10–20% of the population from what I have read. I may be inaccurate on that figure.

Neither, they were Scandinavian (Iceland, Norway, Sweden, Denmark) and therefore Germanic or Teutonic language speakers. If we are going back to the Viking era (about 800–1200), then both the Irish and Scots were overwhelmingly Celtic language speakers. The Viking heritage of both countries is very strong though. Dublin was a Viking colony at one point. Norse Vikings colonised the Scottish islands and significant parts of its North. One of the curious features about Viking settlement in Scotland is that they eventually integrated and became Gaelic speakers over time. Many Scottish clans actually have Viking heritage, e.g. McDonalds, McLeods. But the cultures of Ireland/Scotland and the Vikings were very different.

They were neither. The people we refer to as “Vikings” were the Germanic peoples of Scandinavia; primarily the Norwegians (Norse), Swedes (Rus), and Danes, though there were many other smaller regions and holdfasts ruled by Earls, Jarls, and “Sea Kings". Modern Celts: Scot/Irish/Welsch, certainly have some Scandinavian ancestry due to their regular contact with them, but that was not necessarily by choice. And since some purists will criticize your use of the term Viking, I'll just note that originally it was a verb, not a noun; being the Norse word for raiding and pillaging, but it is perfectly acceptable to use as a noun to describe Scandinavian raiders in modern parlance.

Neither - the Vikings were raiders from what is now modern day Norway. They raided Ireland and the northwest coast of Scotland during the 8th and 9th centuries and settled in Ireland and the Scottish Highlands, and the Hebrides, Shetland and Orkney archipelago and intermarried with the locals. Many of the place names in the Scottish highlands, and the Hebrides, Shetland and Orkney Islands are are of Norse origin such as the village of Tarskavaig on the Isle of Sky, the island of Westray in the Orkney Islands or the village of Skeld on the island of Mainland in the Shetland islands.

Neither they came mostly from Scandinavia, Norway/ Sweden and Denmark but they established seaboard communities all along the North Sea coastline the NE of present day England, western Europe down to France as well as Ireland, Scotland and the north Atlantic such as Iceland and the northern isles of Scotland. Vikings were portrayed as barbaric warlike people who plundered and terrorised where ever they went however today there is a growing view that they were far more advanced and civilised than being fierce warriors with horns on their helmets.

Vikings were a North Germanic peoples from what is now Norway and Sweden (Scandinavia). The French Normans are also related to and descended from the Vikings. They had settled in many places in Europe, including Ireland and Scotland.
